instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to diagnose SSR in oilseed rape?

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to diagnose SSR in oilseed rape?

instruction: What metric was chosen to establish classification models and how far can this metric go in identifying healthy and SSR-infected oilseed rape?
Output: The metric chosen to establish classification models to diagnose SSR in oilseed rape was the classified accuracy. The extreme learning machine (ELM) model achieved a classified accuracy of more than 80.00% in the prediction set. When the ELM model was further improved by using the optimal emission lines, the classified accuracy increased to more than 85%. Therefore, the chosen metric of classified accuracy was able to accurately identify healthy and SSR-infected leaves, with an improvement in accuracy when using the optimal emission lines.

instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the novel approach based on LIBS to diagnose SSR in oilseed rape?
Output:
In the novel approach based on LIBS to diagnose SSR in oilseed rape, four machine learning models were used. These models were K-nearest neighbor (KNN), radial basis function neural network (RBFNN), random forest (RF), and extreme learning machine (ELM). These models were trained using the full LIBS spectra data from 120 fresh leaves, including 60 healthy and 60 SSR-infected leaves. The goal was to establish classification models that could accurately identify healthy and SSR-infected leaves. 

The ELM model, in particular, achieved a classified accuracy of more than 80.00% in the prediction set. Additionally, twenty-four emission lines were selected as the most relevant features to distinguish healthy and SSR-infected leaves using second-derivative spectra. The ELM model was then further improved by using these optimal emission lines, resulting in a classified accuracy of more than 85% and a specificity of 95.00%. 

Overall, the machine learning models were used to analyze the LIBS spectra and classify the leaves as either healthy or SSR-infected based on the patterns and characteristics observed in the data.

instruction: Can the use of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) combined with appropriate chemometric methods be considered a superior and efficient technique compared to traditional methods for diagnosing Sclerotinia stem rot (SSR) in oilseed rape?
Output: Yes, the use of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) combined with appropriate chemometric methods can be considered a superior and efficient technique compared to traditional methods for diagnosing Sclerotinia stem rot (SSR) in oilseed rape. The past study proposes this novel approach as a rapid diagnostic method to prevent the worldwide disease and promote the growth of oilseed rape. The past study found that the LIBS technique, when combined with chemometric methods such as robust baseline estimation (RBE), wavelet transform (WT), and machine learning algorithms like K-nearest neighbor (KNN), radial basis function neural network (RBFNN), random forest (RF), and extreme learning machine (ELM), achieved high accuracy in classifying healthy and SSR-infected leaves. The ELM model, in particular, obtained a classified accuracy of more than 80.00% in the prediction set. Furthermore, by selecting the most relevant emission lines, the ELM model using optimal wavelengths improved the classified accuracy to more than 85% and the specificity to 95.00%. Additionally, the use of optimal wavelengths significantly reduced the number of variables in the models, making the technique more efficient.
